text: have you won today I'm making Hakka
it's a Chinese dumplings normally served
in dim sum it was brought to the UNAM by
the Chinese a long time ago and has
becomes a really popular street foot
snack
they might look quite difficult to make
but it's not impossible to make it home
so let's begin for the dough you're
gonna need 200 gram of tapioca starch
mix it with 200 gram up rice flour the
tapioca starch will give it a nice chewy
texture and also a clear translucent
look the rice flour makes it soft but
please do not use scrutinize rice flour
mix well we'll have a teaspoon of salt
make a well in the center and measure
250 ml of boiling hot water then pour
into the well you a spatula to mix it up
first until the flour and the starch
absorbs all that liquid when it comes
down enough to handle knead well with
your hands until the dough comes
together it's going to take just about 5
to 10 minutes you will get a soft and
smooth dough cover with plastic wrap and
let the dough rest for about 30 minutes
for the fillings you gonna need Bengal
gram of shrimps peeled and deveined use
the flat side of a cleaver to smash them
and then value mix if you prefer
fillings with chunks of shrimps in it
like I do just means half of them and
cut half of them into small cubes season
the shrimps with a tablespoon of minced
garlic and shallots a teaspoon of
chicken stock some pepper a tablespoons
of fish sauce and some chopped green
onions mix well and set aside for about
15 minutes
oh you can also add about a teaspoon of
tapioca or cornstarch so the feelings
can bar together better to shape the
dumplings
grease your hand with some vegetable oil
and then pinch a piece of dough roll it
into a small ball and then flatten it
out into a thin disc
at the shrimp's feelings in the center
and pinch the edges together there are
many ways to shape the dumplings and
this is one of them you want to fall
blitz for half the circle and then pinch
together with the rest of the circle
then stand the dumpling on the palm of
your hand and then bend it a little bit
you can also flatten the dough with your
fingers like this it's easier to control
and shape into a round disk if the other
method is too difficult
this is an easier version you can add
some corn or a characterize in the
center repeat until you finish the dough
and the fillings use your creativity to
shape the dumplings into whatever shape
that you can you can make a lot at a
time and freeze the shaped hack out and
next time when you have cravings just
take out and sting them then line your
steamer with some parchment paper and
place the dumplings into it if you have
one of those bamboo steamers lighting
dim sum restaurants that will be great
I'm just using a normal collapsible
steaming basket here steam for about 20
minutes until the skin of the hakka all
turns quite translucent and you can see
the pink color of the shrimps inside
while they look so nice and delicious
you really should self hackle straight
out of the steamer for the dipping sauce
just mix together some thick soy sauce
some black vinegar and a little bit of
chilli sauce mmm
it tastes so good I can't believe I've
made these if you like them too don't
forget to give this video a thumbs up
and subscribe to my channel for more
delicious Vietnamese foods thank you for
watching bye bye
